data.title: 'Rename Symbol' while editing python often makes no changes.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 6.1.7601
- Python Extension 0.6.4 (Don Jayamanne) installed

This issue has also been replicated on Mac OS 10.12.4 with the same version of VSCode and Python extension.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Right click on variable name.
2. Select 'Rename Symbol'
3. Type in new name and press enter
4. Works less than half of the time. No changes occur to code in most instances.

data.title: Edit jupyter notebooks (Markdown + Code), extension candidate
data.body:
Hi all,
I am writing here since I did not find a proper extension able to edit jupyter notebooks.
The already existing Jupyter extension is nice, but I would like to be able to edit directly a jupyter notebook in order to share it with people using, for instance, the Jupyter notebook web app.
The nteract project is providing some modules which maybe can be used to achieve it.

Thanks,
Francesco

data.title: Clojure mode for .cljc files
data.body:
`.cljc` files don't seem to get recognized as Clojure code and have no syntax highlighting.

See: https://clojure.org/guides/reader_conditionals

- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2)
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open any .cljc file
2. no syntax highlighting

No idea if this is the only place this needs to be configured?
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/clojure/package.json#L13

data.title: make `inspector` the default protocol when a `runtimeExecutable` attribute is set
data.body: Now that Node 8 is out, we should make `inspector` the default protocol for the case when a `runtimeExecutable` attribute is set.

data.title: Defer switching to Tasks 2.0.0 as the default
Can not find preLaunchTask
data.body:
I can only reproduce this with latest from source, not with vscode-insdiers

1. Generate a new TS vscode extension with `yo code`
2. Try to debug it -> notice error that `npm` can not be found

I know you are refactoring thing in the tasks frameworks so just make sure not to break any dependencies debug has on the task frameworks, especailly around debugging extensions

![screen shot 2017-05-31 at 14 50 40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/26632458/8fd2e6fe-4610-11e7-8847-b4a70ddbb4e0.png)

data.title: Tasks: Customized tasks are incomplete
data.body:
Testing: #27443

- follow steps as described in #27443
```
        {
            "taskName": "gulp: watch",
            "identifier": "gulp.watch",
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
        }
```
So this is rather a task decoration to a task. Why not also add command and argument to it?
I think that would be easier to understand for users and make the task self-contained. And the identifier is needed anymore then.

data.title: Extension host crashes on MacOS when crash reporter is disabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0-insider 2017-05-31T05:03:41.769Z
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert `telemetry.enableCrashReporter": false` in workspace settings.
2. Reload VS Code
3. Find out that Intellisense for TypeScript is not working. TypeScript-related commands such as "Open TS Server log" won't do anything.
4. Toggle Developer Tools
5. Find out that extension host could not be started. `TypeError: Cannot read property 'extra' of undefined
    at e.getChildProcessStartOptions (file:///Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.js:28:2214548)`
6. Insert `telemetry.enableCrashReporter": true` in workspace settings.
7. Reload VS Code
8. No errors, works ok.

The offending line is here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/1e54bb/src/vs/workbench/services/crashReporter/electron-browser/crashReporterService.ts#L84

data.title: make ‘inspector’ the default protocol if a 'runtimeExecutable' is set
data.body: Now that Node 8 is out, we should make `inspector` the default protocol for the case when a `runtimeExecutable` attribute is set.

data.title: JSDoc do not generate param for ES6 methods
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create ES6 methods for class
```
method = (num) => {
}
```
2. Enter over method /** and Tab

And see
```
/**
*
*/
```

without 
`* @param num`

data.title: package.json task provider: no "npm install" task suggested if scripts attribute is missing
data.body:
testing #27448:

If a package.json doesn't have a "scripts" attribute, the implicit "npm install" task isn't suggested.

Since "scripts" is not mandatory, I suggest to remove this constraint.

data.title: Task file validation should use error markers

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Testing: #27443

- follow steps as described in #27443
- customize the gulp watch task
- in `tasks.json` add a problem matcher: `"problemMatcher": "dd"`
- error appears in the 'Tasks' output.

Would be nicer to get that error in the tasks.json.
Having the output show messages while typing is quite surprising.

data.title: Tasks.json: Provide intellisense for problem matcher
data.body:
Testing: #27443

- follow steps as described in #27443
- customize the gulp watch task
- in `tasks.json` add a problem matcher 
- no help on the available problem matchers, intellisense would be nice

data.title: Opening a file with "ctrl/cmd p" slow after restart
data.body:
After a restart of VS Code opening a file with "ctrl/cmd p" takes long, as the program has to finish the find in the background.
As we are using VS Code with a remote directory mounted via sshfs we have to restart Code every day and this leads to annoying waiting times in the morning. It should be possible to use the file list from the find before the restart as usually nothing has changed since then.

data.title: Not able to start MERN program using out of the box Debug configuration
data.body:
Testing #27463

- git clone https://github.com/Hashnode/mern-starter.git
- npm install
- cd mern-starter
- code . 
- F5: Launch program. Select `Node.js`

### Issue 1
- It fails because `nodemon` is not installed. 

---
- Install `nodemon`
- Start the program again

### Issue 2 (Mac)
- Debugger stops with time out error

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/26628351/01b4eeec-45fe-11e7-92c6-e6f2c61dadf6.png)

### Issue 3 (Windows)
- Node crashes. Version of node is 6.5

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/26628373/1a6597b6-45fe-11e7-81f8-6c6a69d264b4.png)

data.title: Not showing N further errors or warnings
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/198857/26628013/57f40b80-45f4-11e7-889d-ac8efe4ca08e.png)

Seems like there's a hard coded limit in VSCode for the amount of diagnostics that are allowed to be displayed per file, which is 250:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/6bddd906b09a329fb42e5e7397a676d3dc422c2b/src/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostDiagnostics.ts#L19

In Sublime Text I can display all the phpcs violations in this file which ensures all my new code in the file is correct against coding standards but as it is in VSCode I cannot see new errors because of this limit

Is it possible to expose this limit to user settings?

data.title: which "build" task is picked if I run the "Run Build Task" command?
data.body:
Testing #27448:

- in terminal:
  ```
  git clone https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug
  cd vscode-node-debug
  npm install
  ```
- open project in VS Code and run "Build Task" command

This works fine but I wonder which task definition is used:

- start the "Run Tasks" action,
- scroll through the list to find three(!) definitions for "build"
- (there really should be four build definitions because task.json has another one which just is not named "build")

There should be a visual cue that flags either the single "build" that is used, or all potential "builds".
In the latter case a picker should be used to select the desired build.

data.title: Funny dot rendered in the tab
data.body: * on windows, open the vscode repository * open `node_modules\.bin\gulp.cmd` * create a new top level file `gulp.cmd` Observe, there are two files called `gulp.cmd` opened (one in `$\node_modules\.bin\gulp.cmd` and one in `$\gulp.cmd`. I thought this is a rendering glitch or that I named the file in the wrong way: But I suppose that little dot is the indicator that this is the root `gulp.cmd`. IMHO the little dot should not be rendered in this case, as it appears to be a rendering bug more than an indicator for the root. Perhaps a `\` or nothing at all can be rendered in this case:

data.title: [themes] TypeScript `(this: Type)` parameter color
data.body:
Would be great if it would be possible to change the color of `this` parameter (or make it equal to usual `this` color) when declaring a type of a function scope, so that it doesn't mess with other parameters.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9638588/26626446/ec9f8bfa-45ff-11e7-9575-0509d738c65d.png)

data.title: Add a way to bind a keybinding for a command from the F1 list

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I think we've discussed this, but we've never written it down.

IMHO, it would be very helpful to have an alternative action next to each command in the F1 list (similar how open to the side is an alternative action in the ctrl+p file list) that when executed would bring up the keybindings editor with the action selected and will execute the "edit" action on that command.

e.g. I use `Git: Stage Selected Ranges` and today I always run it from the F1 list because it is not bound. It would be nice to have an action that allows me to record a keybinding for it such that I can easily map it.

data.title: Git gutter diff highlight not refreshing after commit
data.body:
After doing a commit in my git client the gutter marker for changed lines still highlights the lines changed even after the changes have been committed to the repository.

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. make changes to a file within git (I have the repo open in the file explorer)
2. stage and then commit changes to the file
3. observe the highlighting of changed files remains

Closing and reopening the file clears the files changed highlighting, but only until the next commit.
